CatDescriptText: Rosa Glover, housewife, 1760 West Carson Street and Judith Durrah, housewife, West Mifflin, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, December 17, 1960, pg. A1 with question "Do you believe that an accused person, scheduled for an appearance before a jury, is actually judged by a "jury of his peers" (laborers, housewives, rich, poor, Catholic, Jew of Protestant, Negro and white, Northerner, Southerner, Easterner or Westerner, etc.) or is the jury more or less handpicked to satisfy the whims of the prosecution and defense lawyers?"  Mrs. Glover's answer reads: " I don't know because I've never been in court.  The greater percentage of the cases are handled fairly."  Mrs. Durrah's answer reads: "From what I know, the juries are handpicked and this is unfair because everybody should be on the jury..."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Rosa Glover wearing dark plush coat and light colored gloves, standing in front of stone flecked wall; Portrait of Judith Durrah wearing dark double breasted coat with wide collar and head scarf, standing in front of light colored wall
